Tutorial 4: Grid app

Jackson Kwok

2017-11-30

1.1 Introduction

In this tutorial, we introduce a grid-system, which is suitable for apps like these:

1.2 Basic grid

First let’s set up the html with some basic structure.

R code

library(magrittr)
library(jsReact)
create_html() %>% 
  add_js_library("p5") %>% 
  add_title("Grid-based system") %>% 
  add_div(id = "canvas_container") %>% 
  add_script_from_file("grid.js") %>% 
  preview_app()

JS code

// grid.js
function setup() {
  var my_canvas = createCanvas(canvas_width, canvas_height);
  my_canvas.parent("canvas_container");
  rect(0, 0, canvas_width - 1, canvas_height - 1);
}
function draw() {
  plot_data(grid);
}

  • The setup() function set the canvas up and put that into the div container we previously named as ‘canvas_container’. Then we draw a blank rectangle as background.

  • The draw() function is the function that will be called 60 times a second, we call the plot_data() function to plot the grid. We will have to write this function by ourselves. The idea here is that a grid is just a group of boxes at specified coordinates, so we simply need to plot them one by one, then we have a grid! Here is how we do it.

// grid.js (continued)
function plot_data(data0) {
  // suppose data0 stores coordinates in 'x1', 'x2', and color indicators in 'y'
  var n = data0.x1.length;
  for (var i = 0; i < n; i++) {
    if (data0.y[i] == 1) {
      fill(0, 255, 0);  //green color
    } else {
      fill(255, 0, 0);  //red color
    }
    //make a box at (x1, x2) and set box width and height to 20
    rect(data0.x1[i], data0.x2[i], 20, 20);  
  }
}

1.3

1.4 Summary

=======

In this tutorial, we learnt about app deployment and two new widgets.

  • Despite its simplicity, the app deployment part is important as it reveals the true potential of the package. Essentially, this package allows you to port any existing JS libraries to R quite easily, upon which you can build apps and deploy as regular R function calls.

  • For the second part, we talked about how to add buttons with google-material-design icons, and sliders with text that links to the (slider) value.

So that’s it for this tutorial! I shall see you next time.
